This gets a negative 10 from me. I only took it a short while and suffered breakthrough panic attacks or more like terror attacks. Never ever again. If you can handle it, good for you. I wouldn't wish my withdrawals on my worst enemy.

I suffer from extreme anxiety panic attacks and clinical depression, about four years ago I went through episode where my anxiety was non-stop and I was living in constant fear of everything with continuous panic attacks and debilitating depression from it. It was so bad that I was ready to end it till finally one day at the emergency room a doctor gave me 1 mg of this magical drug. As a male in my late 20s and a healthy BMI, my doctor prescribed a trial of this for treatment of generalized anxiety to test its potential efficacy while we sought to establish which, if any, of the benzodiazepines best treated my symptoms. I was absolutely bulletproof to lorazepam. I tried it on a few separate occasions and felt no affect. I then performed a test. I took a dose (1mg) and waited 45 minutes to an hour. When no affect was experienced I then took another. I repeated this process over the span of an afternoon. Even so, there was still no effect. I was not sedated, no less anxious, and experienced no cognitive impact or affect on coordination. I can only hope if I ever need a medical procedure requiring sedation, the doctors do not use lorazepam.

I wasn't the one who had this prescribed but it was prescribed for my 22 yr old daughter who has a history of ODD, ADHD, acute anxiety ,OCD and autism.More recently her OCD has completely taken over her life to the point where I'm her full time carer.So I called in the Calvary.  Big mistake.Her GP prescribed 0.5 up to 1mg of Lorazepam.0.5 did nothing.So we went to 1mg.Omg.She had what I can only describe as a manic episode coupled with rage and tears and wanting to talk for hours. This was 7 days ago and its now thrown her out even more...she could only cope with her OCD to a point NOW that's gone out the window. She is in a continual loop of emotional dysregulation and doesn't know what to do....e.g...she gets upset now over the smallest thing and it triggers increased OCD compulsions and she's stuck, utterly helpless and frustrated and can't stop the intrusive feelings and thoughts. She blames the meds completely.

So I was in a bad car accident back in July of 2021. I still am not back to my normal self and due to the memory loss/lack of sleep/overall issues with basic life tasks. It's been causing me major anxiety/frustration/every emotion under the sun. My doctor put me on Lorazepam for 10 days,  ten days only to help sleep. My doctor didn't want me to stay on it because this can be an addictive drug. I didn't think it was an issue. It did what it was supposed to do. It was 0.5mg and it did help me sleep. The first night I took it, I noticed a lot of heavy/chest deep breathing but the other 10 days I was fine. It was the withdrawal for me which why I DO NOT RECOMMEND IT. I do not drink/smoke/do drugs. I DO NOT have an addictive personality. The first day off of this thing... I cried and cried and cried. So emotional. The littlest things bothered me. I was shaky and irritable. Took everything out on everyone else. Would much rather take something else.
Ativan (lorazepam):The sublingual tablet works quickly. You just feel a wave of calmness come over you.

Ativan (lorazepam):I have been on Ativan in varying dosages for a few years now.  I had a terrible bout of anxiety after an illness years ago and I was unable to eat anything for weeks due to extreme stomach pain.  If I wasn’t prescribed Ativan I don’t know if I would have survived.  I don't that benzos have such a stigma, but for those living with anxiety and all the terrible things that come along with it, it can make living so much better.  At my highest anxiety I was taking 3 mg/day.  I could finally eat and get through the day without pain.  When I am not having issues I take 0.5mg at night to sleep.  If I don’t have it for more than 24 hours I can tell because I will wake up in the middle of the night with anxiety.  I don’t love the fact that it is so addictive, but I don’t know where I would be without it.

Ativan (lorazepam):I initially took this drug to treat chronic nerve pain, as nothing else would work. This gave me some relief as I was experiencing continuous pain. I also suffer from anxiety and bipolar disorder.I believe this drug saved my life, even though it has actually worsen my anxiety. I take 1mg once a day in the morning, so that I would up the next morning with severe anxiety. It took me a long time to figure out this came from Ativan and not my "normal" anxiety, which wasn't that severe in the first place.As my neuralgia eventually got better over time, I tried to lower the dose to 0.5mg per day. I was prepared to experience withdrawal, but instead I felt as great as ever! I eventually went into a manic state and started to have psychotic symptoms.So bipolar people beware: stopping a long term use of Ativan can trigger a manic episode! Altogether I don't regret taking this drug as I have a more productive life and more desire for social connections.

Ativan (lorazepam):This pill works, but is not a solution. Be wary even if you don’t have an addictive personality. I don’t, but using this only 3 days in a row, then stopped, caused me physical withdrawal symptoms! I only took 1mg each day. After 3 days, I had rebound anxiety, tense, painful shoulders and back,  neck/head pain, teeth grinding, and achy. Also, this medication makes my hair shed!! and makes me feel stupid and foggy for days after! This is definitely NOT a drug you want to play around with! My husband was prescribed this years ago, and he said also, he became dope sick after using just for a couple days! Withdrawal from Benzos can be really hard, so if you are trying to get off of them consult your physician. I couldn’t imagine how bad withdrawals would be if you were on these long term. I will keep them on hand for extreme, rare emergencies. But between time, I will stick to hypnosis and taking lemon balm or passionflower herbs.

Hospitalized for a bad auto accident about 30 years ago, I suffered insomnia, anxiety, and depression. My Doctor kept me in the hospital a little over a month trying various combinations of Rxs. He was very happy with the results from 1mg. lorazepam and 2 milligrams trifluoperazine. I have taken them up until 2020. The combo got me thru college with a 4.0 and eased life's dramas and traumas along the way. At the beginning of 2020 I weaned off both with my doctors help. I was never addicted and in fact took less than prescribed going by how my body/mind felt. Weaning off was not hard in anyway- I only take 1/2 mg. lorazepam if necessary.. and I'm finding it not to be. They saved my life! I use natural calmative's and practice healthy wellness alternatives. I would like you to note that over those 30 odd years- I had Doctors that wanted me to try the newest Rx 's - horrid side effects and cost way more... If it ain't broke don't fix it.

Ativan (lorazepam):Ativan works like a charm.  If I'm feeling edgy or having a panic attack, I take 1mg and within 20-30 minutes I'm good for exactly 24 hours.  I would give it a 10, but you really have to take it sparingly and it can be habit forming.  I'd say it's good to take 3-6 times a month, and more frequently than that and you will have some withdrawal symptoms which can be unpleasant (muscle aches, constipation, more anxiety, etc.)  But that's just the nature of Benzos.  Really great drug generally and happy to have access to it in a pinch.

Due to PTSD, I often have vivid nightmares, insomnia, and struggle with anxiety. Ativan has helped me immensely. I take 1mg at night, if needed. My doctor prescribes me 20 at a time, and I usually refill every 4-5 months. A little pill under the tongue, and some soothing binaural beats, makes for a very restful night, without fear. I've never experienced any morning grogginess, or other side effect.

Lorazepam has made me a better person. It is the most effective and reliable medication for my anxiety/insomnia. There will always be people who abuse medications like this but if you take it only when needed and as prescribed it can be life changing. I love everything about this medication. I feel like me! I don’t feel high whatsoever just more calm and more relaxed. It helps me sleep but doesn’t make me zonk out. I take 1-1.5 when needed. I took 2 once during a bad panic attack and it made me extremely tired and sleep all night. Only use when you need it but I’ve found that 0.5-2 is a good dose range for me depending on the level of anxiety or insomnia.

Ativan (lorazepam):This honestly is one of the BESSSSST drugs out there besides Xanax and Valium. I’ve been taking 1mg since July 2018, it makes me feel soooooooo good!! Like a perfectly relaxed almost. I take this usually when I’m having fits of rage, anxiety, panicking or restless legs. When I first take this after a week of awful Ativan withdrawal it feels like literally heaven. I feel so calm and relaxed on this, no paranoia, more talkative and confident, happy and sometimes goofy. The effects last until later the next day. I LOVE this drug! Ativan (lorazepam):Compared to other benzodiazepines, ativan is the best option for me. It lasts 8 full hours, meaning even if addicted. You are more likely to only have to take it twice a day vs a dependent Xanax users 4 times a day. As well as that it seems to be more steady a release, has less side effects than other benzo's and typically a patient only needs 1-2mg a day. (vs Xanax 4mg or 3mg of clonazepam). It's the most logical choice, and the best choice. Just make sure you have a steady supply and taper down when you'd like to stop.
Ativan (lorazepam):Ativan actually is the only medication that can help me get a control on my breathing. And it keeps me from going into panic attacks when I'm loosing control of my breathing.

I started taking Lexapro 10mg 35 days ago and increased it to 20mg 21 days ago and hoped that it would have help more than it did. I was still experiencing anxiety, tension and clenching my jaw at work, home and in my sleep, but Lorazepam Sub 0.5mg helped greatly. been on this for months 2mg x3 a day it helps my anxiety and nerves but Klonopin and Xanax is superior

I have nerve damage in my back from a horribly botched surgery.  It left me with serious issues and unstoppable pain from the waist down including 60% paralyzed on the left side from the waist down.  I was basically given Ativan at the lowest dose .  1 tab up to 3-4 times a day if needed. I wish they hadn’t done that because now I don’t sleep and have serious anxiety.  But yes it worked for me perfect!  Unfortunately many abuse it and ruined my life!  I didn’t have side effects from it but did with many of the other things they tried. It was perfect for me.

Ativan (lorazepam):I fly, on average, once every two months or so.  Over the past few years, there were times when I came SO close to missing flights.  My nervousness and flight anxiety would hit me in my gut at very inopportune times, such as RIGHT before boarding.  I LOVE flying, but can't stand taking off (and to a lesser extent, landing).  I think my flight anxiety really stems from the fact that I'm not in control, I'm relying on a big machine and someone else piloting that machine to get me from point A to point B thousands of feet above the ground.  There's nothing I can personally do except sit there.  So I finally tried Ativan, and I take a very low dosage shortly before flying.  It doesn't take my fear away, but it puts me in a "zone" where it's not completely consuming me.  I always have it on hand!

Lorazepam Intensol (lorazepam):It is important to taper slowly off these drugs - your system will be in flux for years after so it can rebuild natural GABA receptors.  You can use GABA powders to help the process along but not so many supplements that you over ride the process of healing.   I spent three months of tapering off of them.  I did not know they were habit forming till doing research on them years after starting.   Wouldn't be nice if the causes were addressed instead of drugged.

Ativan (lorazepam):I’ve been on 1 mg daily for almost 2 years. I wish I would have known how hard it is to get off of without tapering off slowly. If I miss a dose the rebound symptoms kick in and I’m left in pain, wondering if I’m going to have a grand mal seizure. I want off of this med but I’ll have to talk to my doctor about switching to a slow release to taper off of benzos. If you get prescribed, please only take a small amount for a short period of time. Get a good therapist to find ways to deal with anxiety on your own, this drug is just a bandaid.

I’m so confused. This is supposed to be the best stuff. Took one as prescribed before my flight and it literally didn’t do anything. Then took another- literally nothing. Waste of $14 picking this stuff up

From the very first night, I have had NO horrible images if I  took my 1mg dose. I was stubborn & didn't want to be dependent on a pill, so I  didn't take it every night as prescribed. This medication works tremendously. I have a tolerance to it though and can't get my psychiatrist to prescribe a higher dosage. I suffer horrible anxiety and panic attacks with insomnia and this drug is the miracle cure I needed. One mg in the morning does me good for the day and 1.25mg at night with mirtazapine and amitryptaline and I have the best nights sleep. Even if I only use Ativan. I never need to go above the prescribed dose and its worked well for nearly 2 years now. Better than klonopin, valium and Xanax for what I need it for and lasts a long time in comparison to the others and only temazepam beats it for sleep although tolerance builds quick with temazepam.

I've been taking this almost nightly for the past three-four years to cope with PTSD and anxiety, and it's a lifesaver. I was prescribed 0.5 mL (liquid solution) twice daily, but I only take 0.2 mL and do just fine with that. I sometimes go stretches without taking it, and when I do, the only thing I experience is night sweats. Everyone's different, so check in with your doctor if you feel panicked about any side-effect symptoms. Overall, it's a great and effective medication, as long as it's taken with good judgement and as prescribed.

I took it on and off for a few years and it was so helpful for me; just started it again after 3 months and the Watson's (yes, they do vary), which I took before had a completely different effect; very unpleasant so I discarded them. I take lorazepam as needed for general anxiety and it was such an eye-opener because I have never felt not anxious before. The first time I took it was for a blood test because I'm terrified of blood tests and for the first time in my life, I was able to get out the door without shaking and freaking out. I did find that this medication is really sedating and would last quite a while for me and I'd end up getting light amnesia during the comedowns. Other than that, it's a lifesaver for panic attacks

I found the short-term memory problems to be terrible on 1 mg.  If I was giving a presentation for example, I would have almost no recollection of what I had said.  But now I've reduced to 0.5 mg and it's just as helpful but I feel more lucid and I don't have any memory issues at all.  I take it to reduce the potential to have a seizure.

Ativan (lorazepam):Well, I got an intense anxiety attack at 2 am and somehow went through it that very unfortunate night . But the following morning I got my hands on Ativan and when the anxiety kicked in again I popped 1mg Ativan and it kicked in within an hour and gradually getting stronger.  My heart rate slowed down which made me feel a lot better coz I thought I was gonna have a heart attack during my first anxiety attack . It makes me feel the way that I have won 1 billion dollars
Ativan (lorazepam):It didn't work for anxiety at all. It didn't make me feel calm, but anxious. I felt nauseous, dizzy, itchy, and couldn't sleep. It literally did nothing but side effects.

I was prescribed 1 mg Ativan. I suffer from anxiety and with years of drug abuse behind me I’ve now become a hypochondriac. I was hopeful Ativan would relax my reoccurring panic episodes and extreme social anxiety disorder that has worsened since I kicked opiates.  Ativan solved those problems. I was at ease, I felt relaxed, and my worries were gone. I was able to socialize and express my feelings openly. I felt calm and in control. Yet, I have never in my life experienced the things I felt the following days after taking one single dose of Ativan. The rest of my week was filled with random heart palpitations that woke me up during my sleep, extreme moodiness, and auditory hallucinations. I even had suicidal thoughts for no apparent reason other than I felt I was going crazy and considered it. I took months off and tried it again, same thing happened! I find it disappointing that it works relatively good when you take it but feel even worse days and weeks after a single dose.
It worked great for me. Wished I could have stayed on it long term. I felt normal again.

Ativan (lorazepam):I’ve been on Ativan 0.5mg little over 1 mth and I don't like it. I’m in a constant fog and feel like my body is battling itself internally. I’m a zombie but can’t sleep, I feel like I took uppers and a tranquilizer at the same time. I have the body jerking side effect and when I tried to stop the meds I felt crazy. So I’m taking half and it was better for 2 days and now I’m in a fog again. I am not myself, I can’t function and work is nearly impossible. Helps anxiety but for me not worth it

Ativan (lorazepam):This is a wonderful drug but should not be taken daily. I get ten pills per month. I take them when I have a bad bout of anxiety or insomnia etc. It resets me and stops the panic attack cascade that can happen from nights of insomnia. It parts the waves and allows me to pass through the difficulty. It can make you a little emotional after you stop if you take it a few days. I would not take it more than two or three consecutive days. It can be addictive. It can cause a little forgetfulness. For the most part I felt totally normal. It doesn’t have a weird affect it just takes away the gross fear. I’ve been taking .5-1mg several times per month for 5 years. I average 10 pills per month and have no issue stopping cold turkey. Benzos can be difficult to get off if you take them too frequently so beware.

I have been taking a low dose of lorazepam for years. The last two months I have been feeling different when I take it. Also the pills seem to have a different texture.Sure enough, I called the pharmacist and was told they changed manufacturers two months ago and cannot order from the original manufacturer any longer. Obviously it makes a difference in the manufacturers!

I've been on ativan for only 2 months. At first it worked. Then, I had to take more to get the same calming effect. Now, it makes me feel nausea, headachy, dizziness. I feel awful. And, it hardly takes away the anxiety. I take it to keep the anxiety from coming back, --- 2 mg per day. On top of that, I've developed low blood salt or hyponatremia, a potentially very dangerous condition that has been linked with ativan. I so wish I'd never started it. I see an endocrinologist in 2 days, I so wish I'd never taken ativan and want my former energy and self back, Instead, I feel dull, depressed and miserable. I'm going off ativan (weaning off, which I hear is hard) as soon as possible!!!

Ativan worked a little bit the first time I took it, and I only took it in emergencies when my anxiety was really high. But it lost its effect after a while to the point where it did absolutely nothing for me. I didn't have any issues with withdrawal or side effects, no drowsiness. I wonder if I even took the pill correctly! Anyway I'm on a different medication now so hopefully that actually works for me.

About 2 years ago I started having panic attacks whenever I left the house, and I had terrible insomnia. I was also diagnosed with social anxiety, so I would always feel edgy when around people and this made me quite depressed. I started staying by myself and not going out much. My doctor prescribed 0.5 mg of Lorazepam. I've been taking it almost everyday for one month, and I feel a sense of calm and relief. My mind isn't racing anymore and I'm able to sit still and relax. I'm also sleeping better, and I'm able to concentrate more. I started going out in public again, and I've actually been able to enjoy myself. This medicine is a life-saver for me. I've had some drowsiness, but I just drink a cup of coffee and this helps me to feel alert, but still calm. Now that I'm able to leave the house again, my depression is getting better. I'm a little worried about building a tolerance to this medicine, but so far it's been helping me get my life back on track.

I’ve been on clonazepam that’s ok but not as good as Ativan and I’ve been on Xanax once at the hospital but that made me even more anxious and my muscles jerked. I love Ativan so much
This stuff does NOT work. My doctor prescribed it as a sleep aid and I'm back awake 2 hours later I don't even feel drowsy.

I have been taking Ativan 1 mg 3x day as needed for probably 6 years.  It worked well for a while for my anxiety and was good because it didn’t knock me out.  I was still able to function and not feel like I was in a fog.  Now it’s become completely ineffective.  Tolerance built up and I have a lot of anxiety again.  I keep taking it because I have to or things will be even worse.  It feels like I’m just taking it for no reason though because it’s not doing it’s job.  I’m trying to get my doctor to change it to something else.

I. Love. This. Drug. I take Prozac for my anxiety which helps stabilize me day to day wonderfully, but when my thoughts are racing and my therapy techniques aren’t working and I’m on the verge of a panic attack this drug lorazepam works wonders. I’ll take .5mg and my mind goes quiet and calm within thirty minutes. If I take at night I fall asleep quickly, but I also have no problem staying awake on it if I take during the day. Lorazepam renders you a happy calm and the slightest bit loopy, but not in an incapacitating way. Any mammal reducing or discontinuing certain drugs, like Ativan, can experience dependence, characterized by physical and emotional distress at withdrawal. This is should NOT alone be considered ADDICTION. Addiction often involves dependence, but that's not all. If you discontinue Ativan and find yourself drinking uncharacteristically more, or pursuing other chemical ways to cope, you may have a valid addiction concern.  Phy./emo. dependence, is not the only criteria for AdXN. Dr's are generally accepting of this and should take no offence.
